chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A workable compromise is to keep the Constitution’s state-based role but change how electors are awarded so results better reflect voters everywhere. Congress could set a uniform national rule requiring either proportional allocation in each state (with a small minimum threshold) or a ranked-choice, single national tally used to allocate electors, replacing winner-take-all without erasing federalism. Pair that with baseline standards for ballot access, auditable paper records, and clear recount triggers so close outcomes are trusted and campaigns have incentives to compete beyond a few swing states.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: A durable reform should keep the Electoral College’s state-based framework while reducing winner-take-all distortions so fewer voters feel ignored outside a handful of swing states. A strong middle path is to require a consistent, transparent allocation of electors in every state—preferably proportional (or a clear district-plus-at-large method)—paired with uniform national baselines for ballot access, recount thresholds, auditable reporting, and practical ID options. These steps preserve federalism and stability while making outcomes track the popular will more closely and strengthening trust that every lawful vote is counted fairly.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Any reform should make presidential elections feel fair, easy to understand, and trustworthy while still respecting the role of states and ensuring rural, suburban, and urban communities all matter. A practical compromise is to keep the Electoral College but require a uniform, proportional allocation of electors in every state (ending winner-take-all), with clear national baselines for voter access and integrity—auditable paper trails, transparent recount rules, and secure, non-burdensome ID options. This would reduce “swing state” distortions, make more votes count in every state, and strengthen confidence that the winner earned broad support.
